Award.AwardTitle: Wave Turbulence and Long-Time Dynamics of Dispersive Partial Differential Equations
Award.AbstractNarration:
The great American physicist Richard Feynman described turbulence as the "the most important unsolved problem of classical physics." Here, he was referring to hydrodynamic turbulence, which is the phenomenon one observes on numerous occasions in daily life, particularly when one travels through fluids either in watercraft on the ocean or in airplanes in the atmosphere. Despite its intuitive manifestations, the scientific understanding of turbulence is far from satisfactory. A related phenomenon is "wave turbulence," which pertains to similar problems but for different physical systems involving wave interactions (e.g.,ocean or plasma waves). The aim of this project is to gain a better understanding of certain phenomena pertaining to wave turbulence from a rigorous mathematical viewpoint and thereby to take the first steps towards putting the theory on solid mathematical foundations.

The project addresses two different regimes of long-time behavior for nonlinear dispersive and wave partial differential equations. The first regime can be characterized by "out-of-equilibrium dynamics," in which solutions do not exhibit long-time stability around equilibrium configurations. This is the typical behavior of nonlinear dispersive equations posed on compact domains, where dispersive effects do not translate to decay, and is the natural setting of wave turbulence theory. The other regime of long-time behavior concerns dispersive partial differential equations posed on Euclidean space, for which one can hope to have stable equilibrium points for the dynamics (stationary solutions). The "asymptotic stability" of trivial equilibria (zero solutions) is mostly well understood by now, but that of nontrivial stationary solutions is far from settled. The project suggests several avenues of research to improve our understanding in the two aforementioned directions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:

The aim of the funded project was to advance our understanding of two different regimes of behavior for nonlinear dispersive and wave partial differential equations. The first regime is characterized by "out-of-equilibrium dynamics," in which solutions do not exhibit long-time stability around equilibrium configurations. The main context for this regime is the so-called "wave turbulence theory", which can be defined as the theory of nonequilibrium statistical mechanics of wave systems. On this front, the PI has succeeded in making advances on the projects mentioned in the proposal, most notably the question of deriving the wave kinetic equation (as well as other effective systems that govern the nonequilibrium dynamics) through his joint series of works mainly with Buckmater, Germain and Shatah, and the problem of energy cascade for solutions of the nonlinear Schrodinger equation through his works with Guardia, Haus, Maspero, and Procesi.

The second regime of long time behavior studied by the PI under this project concerns dispersive partial differential equations posed on Euclidean space, for which one can hope to have stable equilibria for the dynamics (stationary solutions). The "asymptotic stability" of trivial equilibria (zero solutions) is mostly well understood by now, but that of nontrivial stationary solutions is far from settled. The PI succeeded to execute the proposed project (with Guo and Nakanishi) to understand the stability problem for the Gross-Pitaevkii equation in 3D (in the radial setting).

Broader Impact:

The questions studied by the PI under the above project have direct impact of the scientific understanding of wave turbulence theory. While the fundamental equations of this theory have been written starting from the 1920's, a proper derivation is still open for the most part. As such, we still lack a good understanding of the regimes and limitations of this theory, which has a direct effect on its applications in oceanography, nonlinear optics, and plasma theory. The PI has forged several connections with physicists and engineers working on these projects, and is still holding regular meetins with them to discuss possible collaborations and sharing expertise. In terms of outreach, the PI has strived to encourage and introduce researchers (particularly early career ones) into this important direction of research through forging new collaborations, organizing workshops and conferences, inviting speakers to seminars at his home institutation, and teaching topics classes (and learning seminars) on related topics.
